correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is indicated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for future entry subsections.

list.item: Encoding uses the recommendations for Level 3 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines.
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Running headers and side descriptions are not included.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, small caps, strike-through, subscript, superscript, underline. The following formatting is ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze.
Subject-level metadata was added to each entry using the HIVE automated vocabulary server created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: The first release is a reproduction of text matter for all entries. It does not include images, tables, formulae, front- or back-matter. It omits volume 1, which consists of "Dissertations" rather than entries.

div.p: TAM, commonly called Rabbenu Tam, more correctly Rabbenu Tham (∏""∣=D∏ ∙123Ι). By this title are known two eminent Rabbinic scholars, both named Ya'akob, to whom this epithet was given in allusion to Genesis xxv. 27: “And Jacob was a perfect man” (fish Tam, ÛR ^*N). They belonged to the north of France, lived in the 12th century, and were master and pupil.

1. Rabbenu Ya'akob b. Meir b. Shemuel was, on his mother’s side, a grandson of Rashi(q.vf. He was his parents’ third son, younger brother of Ribam and Rashbam(q.vi), older brother of Rabbenu Shelomoh of Rameru,
See MS. Add. 27,200 in the Br. Mus., leaf 158t>. and brother-in-law of Rabbenu Shemuel b. Simhah of Vitry the younger
See Rashi’s Siddur, i. leaf Ιό. (the reputed author of the Mahzor Vitry,
See Schiller-Szinessy, Catalogue, ii. p. 88. i now apparently lost
See art. Rashi (vol. xx. p. 284, note 10).). Rabbenu Tham had, like his grandfather Rashi, six teachers (1) his own father, (2) his brother Ribam, (3) his brother Rashbam, (4) Rabbenu Ya'akob b. Shimshon,
This rabbi was a disciple of R. Shemuel Hallevi (see Schiller-Szinessy, Catal., ii. p. 65, note 1) and of Rashi, and was not only a great Talmudist, as were all the disciples of the last-named eminent teacher, but also a great mathematician and astronomer, though a terribly bad poet. His commentary on Aboth is in part printed, and is to be found, more or less perfect, in various libraries in Europe, although not recognized as his. It is ascribed variously to Rashi, to Rashbam, and others. There are copies of it in Cambridge (Add. 1213; Add. 1523), Oxford (Opp. 317), the British Museum (Add. 27201), the Beth Hammidrash of the Ashkenazim in London, &c. (The master of St John’s, Cambridge, is preparing an edition of it.) A work on intercalation by Rabbenu Ya'akob b. Shimshon exists in MS. at the Bodleian (Opp. 317) under the name of Sepher Haelkoshi. From him, no doubt, Rabbenu Tham imbibed his love for science. On the fact that Rabbenu Ya'akob b. Shimshon was Rabbenu Tham’s teacher (against Zunz), see Schiller-Szinessy, Catal., ii. p. 66, note. (5) his grandfather Rashi,
Rabbenu Tham, dying an old man, must have been from fourteen to sixteen years of age when Rashi died. and (6) Rabbenu Yoseph Tob-'Elem the younger.
See Sepher Hayyashar, § 620 (leaf 74α, col. 2). Rabbenu Tham had at least five children.
See Camb. MS. Add. 667, 1, leaf 645, col. 1. The names of three of his sons were Yoseph,
See Brit. Mus. MS. Add. 27200, leaf 158δ. Yishak,
See Sepher Hayyashar, § 604. and Shelomoh.
See Shibbole Halleket (ed. Buber), p. 10. Rabbenu Tham was unquestionably among Jews the foremost man of his age. For not only was he the greatest Talmudist after his maternal grandfather’s death, but he also added reading wide and varied to a stupendous memory and a marvellous
power of combination, such as appeared only again in the last century in the persons of R. Yehonathan Eybenschiitz (06. 1764) and R. Yehezkel Landau (ob. 1793). Let us add that he was a lexicographer, grammarian, and Biblical commentator of no mean order; that he was a poet in Hebrew and Aramaic
See his Yesib Pithgam (in the Ashkenazic ritual; it is introductory to the prophetic lesson for the second day of Pentecost). If we have the correct reading of that poem there, Rabbenu Tham must have been a Levite; and if so, the Shemuel Hallevi mentioned by R. Ya'akob b. Shimshon as his teacher, in the Cambridge MS. Add. 1213, leaf 275, is very possibly Rabbenu Tham’s paternal grandfather. inferior only to Ibn Gebirol (Avicebron,q.v.), Mosheh Ibn 'Ezra, and Yehudah Hallevi (and by far greater in this art than the commentator Abraham Ibn 'Ezra); that he was held in high esteem by prince and nobles;
See Sepher Hayyashar, § 595 (leaf 67α, col. 1), and § 610 (1st) in fine. To this high position it is no doubt to be ascribed that his life was saved by a knight during the second crusade, in which the whole congregation of Rameru was reduced to beggary, after many of its members had been ruthlessly slain. and that he was a man of great wealth, with which he generously supported, not merely his own poorer hearers, but other itinerant scholars also.
For example, the poverty-stricken Abraham Ibn 'Ezra, to whom he not only gave money but kind words also, in good verses (Kerem Hemed, vii. p. 35).

(1) Commentary on Job, and, no doubt, on other parts of the Bible (see Camb. Univ. Lib. MS. Dd. 8. 53, leaves 15, 4a, lla, 12b). All these are apparently now lost. (2) Hakhrdoth, i.e., lexical and grammatical decisions between Menahem Ibn Seruk and Dunash b. Labrat (see Sepher Teshuboth I) unash b. Labrat, Edinburgh, 1885, 8vo). That these “decisions” are really by Rabbenu Tham is proved by the before-named MS., leaves 10α and 16α, where the book is quoted by an author of the 13th century. (3) Sepher Hayyashar (Vienna, 1810, folio). Although this work, in its present form, is the compilation of one of Rabbenu Tham’s disciples, R. Yishak b. Durbal by name (also called Isaac of Russia; see Schiller-Szinessy, Catalogue, i. p. 164, and ii. p. 66), not only is the foundation Rabbenu Tham’s (see Preface), but the contents also are virtually his. Compare the Cambridge MS. Add. 667. 1, passim. (4) The greater part of the Tosaphoth in the Babylonian Talmud are indirectly also by Rabbenu Tham; and he is virtually the first Tosaphist. It is true that his father, his brother Rashbam(q.v.), and his uncle Rabbenu Yehudah b. Nathan had written Tosaphoth before him, and that this kind of literary activity lasted to within the first quarter of the 14th century. Still, most and the best of the Tosaphoth now in our hands rest on Rabbenu Tham and his school. (5) Mahzor, i.e., a prayer-book, &c., for the whole year, with Rabbinic ordinances, &c. See Tosaphoth on T. B., Berakhoth, leaf 37α, catchword DD12Π, and Birekhoth Maharam of R. Meir b. Barukh of Rothenburg (Riva di Trento, 1558, 8vo), leaf 4α. (6) Poems. These are partly didactic and partly liturgical. Of the former kind a specimen will be found (“On the Accents,” communicated by Halberstam) in Kobak’s Yeshurun, v. p. 125 sq. The liturgical poems, again, are of two kinds: (a) such as have no metre and rhyme only by means of plurals, possessive pronouns, and such like (rhymed prose), and which perfectly resemble most of the productions of the Franco-Ashkenazic school (see, for example, the facsimile in Muller’s Catalogue, Amsterdam, 1868, 8vo); {b) such as have metre and rhyme, and resemble the productions of the Sepharadic school, e.g., the one beginning TVD "p " n (and not ΊΠ; see MS. Add. 667, leaf 102α).
For other metrical poems by Rabbenu Tham, see Zunz, Literaturg. der Syn. Poesie (Berlin, 1865, 8vo), p. 266. (7) Various ordinances, &c., are to be found in later writers (see AIS. Add. 667, in Cambridge, passim, and Teshuboth Maharam, Prague, 1608, folio, § 1023, he.). Rabbenu Tham died in 1171; see Rashi’s Siddur, ii. (formerly Luzzatto’s, then Halberstam’s, and now the property of the master of St John’s College, Cambridge), leaf 48α.

2. Rabbenu Ya'akob of Orleans, rabbi of London (?). He is often quoted in the Tosaphoth (both on the Pentateuch and on the Babylonian Talmud). No independent works of his, however, are extant. He was killed at London in the tumult on the coronation day of Richard Coeur-de-Lion (September 3,1189; Schiller-Szinessy, Catal., i. p. 117). (s. Μ. s.-s.)
